cab.content: [This Document is the Property of His Britannic Majesty s Government.]Printed for the Cabinet. March 1922.SECRET.CP. 3816.CABINET. SPECIAL WEEKLY REPORT ON UNEMPLOYMENT. No. 60. t WEEK ENDED MARCH 3, 19220 THE SITUATION. There are still no signs of a general trade revival. Employment in coal-miningremains about the same. More regular time is being worked. The slight improve-ment in the steel and iron trade has continued, but there are no signs of a generalresumption. In shipbuilding and marine engineering no developments are reported.Ship-repairing is still fairly active. In the cotton industry a slight improvement inthe number of hours worked has taken place. Woollen industry still continues toimprove slowly. There has been a temporary improvement in, the silk trade.Employment in the hosiery trade remains good. General engineering shows no improvement; the threatened lock-out overshadows the whole position. The slightimprovement in the motor and cycle section has been maintained. Building industryshows a very slight improvement, mainly in "house decoration." The pottery and china industry shows signs of a revival. Glass manufacture, however, shows signsof depression. T. J. MACNAMARA, Ministry of Labour, NOTE ON UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION IN UNITED KINGDOM ON MARCH 3, 1922. 1. The Trade Union figure of unemployment for July 1914 was 2-8 per cent. The average for the ten years prior to the war, according to Trade union unemployment figures, was 4-7 per cent. It was as high as 7-8 per cent, in 1908 and7-7 per cent, in 1909. During 1919 it ranged between 1-6 per cent, in September and 3-2 per cent, inDecember, and averaged 2-4 per cent, for the year. During 1920 it ranged between 0-9 per cent, in April and 6-0 per cent, inDecember, and averaged 2-4 per cent, for the year. The figures for 1921 were: To the endof Per cent. " Workpeople who are unable so to comply are excluded.I.-SUMMARY OF ACTION TAKEN BY THE GOVERNMENT. [From Autumn 1920 to Autumn 1921.] Cabinet Unemployment Committee, The prospect of a severe trade depression first became evident in the early autumn of 1920. On the 13th August, 1920, there was a special discussion at a meetingof the Cabinet, when the Cabinet Unemployment Committee was appointed toconsider the whole question and devise means for relieving unemployment. [This Committee has since been in constant session and has, up to the 3rdMarch, 1922, held 42 meetings. The problem of unemployment in one form or another has also been before theCabinet on 58 occasions between the 13th August, 1920, and the 3rd March, 1922.] (A.) Unemployment Insurance. An Unemployment Insurance Bill of general scope was passed into law on the9th August, 1920, and came into operation on the 8th November following. TheAct applied compulsory' insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons ascompared with 4,000,000 previously. Subsequent amending Acts modified theconditions as regards rates of benefit and the amount thereof which could be drawn.Contributions were also increased and authority given to borrow money from theTreasury up to 20,000,000. (B.) Emergency Works and other Measures. A full statement of the measures taken in the autumn of 1.920 and of the latermeasures from autumn 1.921 onwards has been set out in previous issues of thisReport. At least 250,000 men have had employment on these schemes at various times, and at the present time over 131,000 men are employed, exclusive of the workprovided for men in ancillary occupations and the effect of the Export Credits andTrade Facilities Act schemes (see table below). On the 25th February, the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries issued a circular Letter to all County Councils (except the London County Council)authorising an extension of the land drainage scheme to include works for theprovision and improvement of water supply to farms.
